questions.question_text:
A security administrator is choosing an algorithm to generate password hashes.
Which of the following would offer the BEST protection against offline brute force attacks?

discussion.content:
If this comes up I'm putting down SHA-1.
At least I fail with dignity.
I agree D, AES is for encryption not hashing

comments.content: AES can be used as a keyed hashing function. The weakness with this approach that a hash doesn't have is that if you figure out the key you can decrypt ALL the passwords. The answer here is absolutely wrong.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
SHA1=160bits

you protect password with hash algorithm not with encryption algorithm Answer is D Sha 1
A hash is not ‘encryption’ – it cannot be decrypted back to the original text (it is a ‘one-way’ cryptographic function, and is a fixed size for any size of source text). This makes it suitable when it is appropriate to compare ‘hashed’ versions of texts, as opposed to decrypting the text to obtain the original version.
MD5=128 bits, SHA1=160bits, RIPEMD is up to 320 bits.
D should be the answer. AES not used for hashing and only MD5 and SHA1 in this question are used for hashing. When compared SHA1 is more secure

Strong algorithms
• PGP, AES

comments.content:
AES is not used to generate hashed full stop
The most secure hashing algorithm here is sha-1

discussion.content: I think the first sentence is placed to throw us off. The real question is what algorithm is uncrackable by offline brute force attack- in that case AES. even though AES is not a hashing algo, they are not asking what's used to hash; they are simply asking what stands better agains an off-line brute force.

Oline brute force attack= SHA-1
Offline brute force attack=AES

comments.content: nvm i think offline password attack protection can be protected with SHA-1. D is correct as others said.

discussion.content: "Which of the following would offer the BEST protection ". MD5 and SHA-1 are hashing algorithms. They don't provide protection. AES is correct.

This question is wrong, there’s a mistake on the 3rd choice, it should be : C. RIPEMD 
Which is more secure than MD5 & SHA.
Much more reliable source : A security administrator is choosing an algorithm to generate password hashes. Which would offer the BEST protection against offline brute force attacks?

MD5, 3DES, RIPEMD, SHA-1

comments.content: Where did you find that RIPEMD is better then SHA-1? It’s only the case if they use RIPEMD320

discussion.content: I will go with SHA-1 unless the moderators can provide a valid reason they choose AES. I hope they aint just doing copy and paste

comments.content: The moderators do not provide these answers.

discussion.content: Keyword: Password Hashes. So it cannot be AES. It must be D (SHA1), because it is more secure than MD5.
AES is the correct answer. Whirlpool is a HASH that uses modified version of AES.
D is the correct answer here. MD5 and SHA-1 are both hashing algorithm but SHA-1 is a better hashing algorithm
Agreed D is correct

comments.content: First of all, AES is not a hash algorithm. Second, it is still possible to find a hash collision by brute force or use rainbow attack. That's why to choose SHA for better security.

discussion.content:
Sorry type. Old tablet lol
the correct answer is C. the key word is "offline" if a hacker steals the hashes and then takes them home to try brute force. He wont be able to crack rhe the hash if it is encrypted. I did some research on this. EE times website says the AES is prevents offline brute force attacks

thw corrsct answer is C. the key word is "offline" is a hacker steals the hashes and then takes them home to try ans try again to brute force. He wnt be able to the hash is encrypted. I did some research on this. EE times website says the AES is prevents offline brute force attacks

A. MD5 = hashing algorithm although sha is better
B. 3DES = symmetric encryption algorithm 
C. AES = symmetric encryption algorithm
D. SHA-1 = Hashing algorithm (better than MD5)
 Answer = D. SHA-1
3DEs and AES are block ciphers for encrypting data, where MD5 and SHA-1 are hashing functions. MD5 and SHA-1 aren't considered secure anymore, but SHA-1 is the stronger of the two.
I was thinking D as well. I looked at 4 other sites and they all say C. ?!?!?!?!

So i agree with the other two comments that it probably should be D. BUT consider CompTIA likes to bait you into the wrong answers. Technically you can disregard to the first statement. If you disregard the first statement in the question, the answer is AES.

comments.content: 3DEs and AES are block ciphers for encrypting data, where MD5 and SHA-1 are hashing functions. MD5 and SHA-1 aren't considered secure anymore, but SHA-1 is the stronger of the two.

discussion.content: D is correct
D: SHA1

comments.content:
Copy/Paste from below...this guy says the answer C is correct on the test because C. RIPEMD will be your actual choice! He states it emphatically, like it is fact! On people finding ways to justify C. AES...imagine the cpu cycles involved to decrypt your hashes that were subsequently encrypted with AES....AND why even bother hashing the password if you were just going to encrypt with AES anyway? This makes no sense in real life scenarios but I get it, IT'S COMP TIA...just pay attention, and if you see this question, please watch answer C and if it is indeed RIPEMD, then go with that and PLEASE report back to help your fellow man!! NOW PASTING HIS COMMENT
This question is wrong, there’s a mistake on the 3rd choice, it should be : C. RIPEMD 
Which is more secure than MD5 & SHA.
Much more reliable source : A security administrator is choosing an algorithm to generate password hashes. Which would offer the BEST protection against offline brute force attacks?

MD5, 3DES, RIPEMD, SHA-1
I am guessing the answer should be SHA -1, unless one of the option is RIPEMD -256 / 320. Am I right ?

questions.question_text:
A security administrator is investigating many recent incidents of credential theft for users accessing the company's website, despite the hosting web server requiring HTTPS for access. The server's logs show the website leverages the HTTP POST method for carrying user authentication details.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for compromise?

choices.B: The web server is running a vulnerable SSL configuration.
choices.C: The HTTP response is susceptible to sniffing.
choices.A: The HTTP POST method is not protected by HTTPS.

discussion.content:
Answer should be B.
Once SSL/TLS is in use, everything should be encrypted which includes GET, POST, URL etc

There has to be a SSL vulnerability which the attacker is able to exploit

comments.content: its a given CompTIA is gonna ask atleast 5-7 questions never seen before. just hope some are beta questions

discussion.content: Once again another question that IS NOT COVERED IN ANY SECURITY PLUS MATERIAL. its so frustrating man. I am new! How the hell am i supposed to know if POST is encrypted in flipping HTTPS???? That isn't in Prof Messer or Gibson's.....

Why option A cannot be the answer? 
Explanation for the same: https://https.cio.gov/faq/#what-information-does-https-protect
Answer is B - POSTS, GETS, etc are encrypted within a HTTPS connection, you do not need (nor even exists) HTTPS GET and HTTPS POST within HTTPS.

HTTP POST is not encrypted, it can be intercepted by a network sniffer, by a proxy or leaked in the logs of the server with a customised logging level. Yes, POST is better than GET because POST data is not usualy logged by a proxy or server, but it is not secure. ... It is not secure.Jun 18, 2009 ....just google it ?

*** Please Read:
The correct answer is B. 

The reason why is not A is because The process is:
1. SSL handshake 
2. Encrypted data (no matter if it is post or request)

https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ssl/why-is-http-not-secure/

Why the correct answer is B? Because SSL v1 and v2 and even TLS v1 is susceptible to be hacked.

HTTP POST is not encrypted, it can be intercepted by a network sniffer, by a proxy or leaked in the logs of the server with a customised logging level. Yes, POST is better than GET because POST data is not usualy logged by a proxy or server, but it is not secure.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1008668/how-secure-is-a-http-post#:~:text=Yes%2C%20POST%20is%20better%20than,browser%20(see%20RFC%202617).

comments.content:
IN HTTP POST isn't encrypted but in HTTPS it is.Yes, POST data should be encrypted. Everything in the HTTP request should be encrypted in an SSL conversation

https://serverfault.com/questions/106905/is-post-data-encrypted-over-an-ssl-connection

discussion.content: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downgrade_attack

Technically the statement made in the answer A is false, because as MagicianRecon wrote above, the HTTPS protocol protects all, included the data sended using HTTP POST method. 

I really can't understand how a clearly false statement, could be the right answer; nevertheless ALL the sources I found, indicate this answer as correct; so if it were considered correct (for some inexplicable reasons) from CompTIA authors, I wouldn't be so surprise, because after reading dozens of absurd questions and answers, nothing amazes me anymore. Maybe striving at all costs to find something that really makes sense in these questions, might not be the best way to take this exam.

Anyway if I should look for a reasonable answer, B could be fine; but I wouldn't even rule out the possibility that the whole incident might be due to a redirection to a spoofed website as a result of a DNS poisoning (so even answer D might be a possibility).

comments.content:
Hope this helps for the confusion:
… In practice, HTTPS can protect communication with a domain even in the absence of DNSSEC support. … (https://https.cio.gov/faq/#how-does-https-protect-against-dns-spoofing)

discussion.content:
Answer should be B.
According to 2 sources over Internet, POST should be encrypted by HTTPS, which sounds normal and logic.
https://serverfault.com/questions/106905/is-post-data-encrypted-over-an-ssl-connection
Would this not be C as that’s what actually contains the credentials in the http response?

questions.question_text:
A user from the financial aid office is having trouble interacting with the finaid directory on the university's ERP system. The systems administrator who took the call ran a command and received the following output:
//IMG//

Subsequently, the systems administrator has also confirmed the user is a member of the finaid group on the ERP system.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for the issue?

discussion.content:
Answer A is correct.

Explanation:
finaid directory permissions drwx---r-- in the image means that owner has full permissions, group members have none, and others have read only access. In order for the finaid group members to have full access to the directory you need the 2nd set of rwx permissions to show instead of dashes.

https://ryanstutorials.net/linuxtutorial/permissions.php

comments.content: Correct since the question stated the user was not able to "interact" meaning no modifying, writing or anything. Only thing the "other" group will have is read with the r--. Need to have rwx for the second set and having rwx for other still works.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Agree with frkngenius

It's obvious. The user belongs to the group finaid, but from this ls-l Linux command, we can see that the user for the directory finaid has an improper group assignment, the name of the group is "common".
admin owner, common group, finaid directory. 
it shoul be
admin owner, finaid group, finaid direcory

D is correct
Answer A is not a good standard practice; you dont set 777 for primary application directory . Change group ownership to "finaid" and limit users who are allowed to be in this group.

comments.content: Yes opening up file to world readable would fixe the issue, but What security centric sysadmin ever change a file to 777, if you do this for a living a this goes against everything you been taught.

discussion.content: Why would anyone chmod to drwxrwxrwx to a directory with financial info? Why would you give world complete access. Doesn't make any sense. Maybe drwxrwx--- depending on the needs but not wide open.
Is the provided answer correct?
I doubt A. Choice D makes me see the 'common' group, The user is from the Financial Aid Office....they should have their own group with permissions.

choices.B: The problem is local to the user, and the user should reboot the machine.
choices.A: The permissions on the finaid directory should be drwxrwxrwx.
choices.D: The finaid directory has an improper group assignment.
choices.C: The permissions on the finaid directory should be d---rwx---.

questions.question_text:
An organization wants to deliver streaming audio and video from its home office to remote locations all over the world. It wants the stream to be delivered securely and protected from intercept and replay attacks.
Which of the following protocols is BEST suited for this purpose?

discussion.content: The Secure Real-time Transport Protocol (SRTP) is a security framework that extends the Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP) and allows a suite of crypto mechanisms

SRTP encodes the voice into encrypted IP packages and transport those via the internet from the transmitter (IP phone system) to the receiver (IP phone or softphone), once SIPS has initiated a secure connection
Or E: Have the marketing head fired, if they don't understand PII, because they pose a risk for the company.

Is this a real question? It's so odd. With the "favorite ice cream flavors, change from the top down usually succeeds, quietly record the incident" it's hard to believe that this is actually on the test
Data Privacy Officer (DPO)—this role is responsible for oversight of any personally identifiable information (PII) assets managed by the company.

privacy officer, also known as a privacy compliance officer, develops and modifies privacy policies and practices of an organization or business. As a privacy officer, your duties include assessing current policies, suggesting modifications, and training new and existing employees on these policies.
CompTia is really frustrating

comments.content: my favorite ice cream flavor is anguish
I would love to share what my favourite ice cream is but don’t want my identity stolen.

questions.question_text:
A manager makes an unannounced visit to the marketing department and performs a walk-through of the office. The manager observes unclaimed documents on printers. A closer look at these documents reveals employee names, addresses, ages, birth dates, marital/dependent statuses, and favorite ice cream flavors. The manager brings this to the attention of the marketing department head. The manager believes this information to be PII, but the marketing head does not agree.
Having reached a stalemate, which of the following is the MOST appropriate action to take NEXT?

choices.B: Find the privacy officer in the organization and let the officer act as the arbiter.
choices.D: To maintain a working relationship with marketing, quietly record the incident in the risk register.
choices.C: Notify employees whose names are on these files that their personal information is being compromised.
choices.A: Elevate to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) for redress; change from the top down usually succeeds.
